Question: A teacher makes the following statement to her class: 'If you get an A on the final exam, then you will pass the course.' Which of the following situations would prove that the teacher's statement is false?

A) A student gets an A on the final exam and passes the course.
B) A student gets an A on the final exam and fails the course.
C) A student does not get an A on the final exam and passes the course.
D) A student does not get an A on the final exam and fails the course.

Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I've got this logic problem here, and I need to figure out which situation would prove that the teacher's statement is false.
The teacher said, "If you get an A on the final exam, then you will pass the course." Hmm, okay, so it's a conditional statement.

In logic terms, that would be "If P, then Q," where P is "getting an A on the final exam" and Q is "passing the course."

Now, the question is asking which situation would make the teacher's statement false.
I remember that in logic, a conditional statement "If P, then Q" is only false when P is true and Q is false.
So, to disprove the teacher's statement, we need a case where a student gets an A (P is true) but doesn't pass the course (Q is false).

Let me look at the options again:

A) A student gets an A and passes the course.
Well, if P is true and Q is true, that's actually supporting the teacher's statement, right? It doesn't disprove it.
So A isn't the one.
B) A student gets an A and fails the course.
Okay, here P is true and Q is false.
That fits the condition where the conditional statement is false.
So B seems like a candidate.
C) A student doesn't get an A and passes the course.
Here, P is false, and Q is true.
But wait, the conditional statement "If P, then Q" is true in this case because the statement only makes a claim when P is true.
If P is false, the statement doesn't say anything about Q.
So this doesn't disprove the teacher's statement.
It might even support it indirectly because not getting an A doesn't necessarily mean you'll fail.
D) A student doesn't get an A and fails the course.
So P is false and Q is false.
Again, since the statement only talks about what happens when you get an A, this doesn't directly disprove it.
It's possible that not getting an A could lead to failing, but that's not the same as disproving the conditional statement.
So, after thinking through each option, it looks like option B is the one that directly contradicts the teacher's statement by showing that getting an A doesn't guarantee passing.
Therefore, the teacher's statement is false in this situation.

</think>

The situation that disproves the teacher's statement is when a student gets an A on the final exam but fails the course.
B) A student gets an A on the final exam and fails the course.
